verb.description: Be carried slowly by a current of air or water.
examples: the cabin cruiser started to drift downstream
excited voices drifted down the hall

verb.description: (especially of snow or leaves) be blown into heaps by the wind.
examples: fallen leaves start to drift in the gutters

noun.description: A continuous slow movement from one place to another.
examples: there was a drift to the towns

noun.description: The general intention or meaning of an argument or someone's remarks.
examples: maybe I'm too close to the forest to see the trees, if you catch my drift
he didn't understand much Greek, but he got her drift

noun.description: A large mass of snow, leaves, or other material piled up or carried along by the wind.
A horizontal or inclined passage following a mineral vein or coal seam.

origin: Middle English (in the sense mass of snow, leaves, etc.): originally from Old Norse drift snowdrift, something driven; in later use from Middle Dutch drift course, current, and (in drift (sense 6 of the noun)) South African Dutch drift ford; related to drive.
